duck: Continued  is the second album released by Tony Joe White.
To go on with a particular action or in a particular condition; persist.

wiki.text:
{{Infobox album | Name = Continued Type = Studio | Artist = Tony Joe White Cover = Continued.jpg Background = Released = 1969 | Recorded = October 1968 Genre = Country, pop, blue-eyed soul, swamp rock | Length = Label = Monument Records Producer = Billy Swan Last album = [[Black | and White (Tony Joe White album)|Black and White]]
(1968) This album = | 'Continued'
(1969) Next album = [[Tony Joe]]
(1970) Misc = | {{Singles Name =Black and White Type =studio Single 1 =Roosevelt And Ira Lee | Single 1 date =1969 Single 2 =Old Man Willis Single 2 date =1970 Single 3 = | Single 3 date = }} {{Extra album cover | Upper caption = Alternative cover Type = cover Cover = Continued2.jpg Alt = | Lower caption = 1993 Reissue cover with new title (Roosevelt And Ira Lee) }} }} {{Album ratings |rev1 = Allmusic |rev1score = [ Allmusic review] }} 'Continued' is the second album released by Tony Joe White. It was released on Monument Records and contained the single Roosevelt and Ira Lee It was recorded at Monument Studios, Nashville and Lyn-Lou Studios, Memphis in 1969. It was produced by Billy Swan and engineered by Tommy Strong and Mort Thomasson. The album was re-released on by Movieplay/Intermusic from Portugal in 1993 with a different cover and another title (Roosevelt And Ira Lee). In 1997 it was rereleased by Warner Brothers containing two additional songs - "Watching The Trains Go By" (by Dewey Oldham and Wallace Pennington) and "Old Man Willis" (by Tony Joe White himself) was the second single. "Old Man Willis" was later re- recorded for the album. The album contained the track "Rainy Night In Georgia" popularized by R&B vocalist Brook Benton in 1970. It reached #4 on the Pop Singles and #2 on the Adult Contemporary charts, respectively. The RIAA certified the single gold for sales of one million copies. In 2004, it was ranked #498 on the List of Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Songs of All Time. The song has been covered by a number of musicians, including Ray Charles, Otis Rush, Randy Crawford, Tennessee Ernie Ford, Amos Garrett, Hank Williams, Jr., Shelby Lynne, John Holt, by the duet of Conway Twitty and Sam Moore, Aaron Neville, and reggae band The Gladiators. Most recently indie folk-rock band Hem released a cover on [[No Word from Tom]] (2006). Australian band Ross Hanniford Trio recorded a cover of the song on their 1994 album. Interestingly, David Ruffin recorded a cover version of the song the same year as Benton, however, Motown for unknown reasons did not release the album. A dance version was recorded by Boozoo Bajou in 2006.
wiki.title: continued
